--- title: "Ordinal regression" author: Vladimir Buskin format: html: self-contained: false logo: logo.png footer: "Regression" theme: Reference toc: true number-sections: true slide-number: true incremental: false slide-level: 4 scrollable: true editor: visual bibliography: R.bib --- ## Suggested reading > @powersStatisticalMethodsCategorical2008: Chapter 7; > @baguleySeriousStatsGuide2012: Chapter 17.4.5 ## Introduction In her recent contribution, @glassEnglishVerbsCan2021 examines possible reasons why certain transitive verbs have a stronger affinity towards object omission compared to others, placing special emphasis on the routinisation of the actions denoted by the verbs. Specifically, she analyses **how high/low-routine contexts affect the acceptability of object omission** for transitive verbs from different frequency bins. We will replicate her findings using her survey data `Glass_2021_survey_processed.csv`[^ordinal_regression-1]: [^ordinal_regression-1]: The original dataset can be retrieved from Lelia Glass's OSF repository: \[Last accessed: 27th September, 2024\]. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load libraries library(tidyverse) library(ordinal) # Load data survey <- read.csv("Glass_2021_survey_processed.csv") # Inspect dataset str(survey) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 'data.frame': 784 obs. of 5 variables: $ rating : int 3 4 3 3 2 4 3 2 3 2 ... $ freq : chr "hi" "lo" "lo" "hi" ... $ verb : chr "pick" "catch" "throw" "break" ... $ ParticipantID: chr "Participant1" "Participant1" "Participant1" "Participant1" ... $ routine : chr "hi" "lo" "lo" "lo" ... ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} head(survey) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` rating freq verb ParticipantID routine 1 3 hi pick Participant1 hi 2 4 lo catch Participant1 lo 3 3 lo throw Participant1 lo 4 3 hi break Participant1 lo 5 2 hi taste Participant1 hi 6 4 hi bottle Participant1 hi ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="Short breakdown of the variables"} - `routine`: In Glass's study, transitive verbs were randomly assigned to one of the following conditions: > - (High routine condition:) I worked at my poultry farm. Just like I > always do, I butchered some chickens. Then I gathered some eggs. > > - (Low-routine condition:) I visited a friend's job. Just because > people wanted me to try it, I butchered some chickens. Then I went > for a walk. > > Cf. Glass [-@glassEnglishVerbsCan2021: 66] ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(survey$routine) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "hi" "lo" ``` ::: ::: - `rating` records the responses of participants to a follow-up question regarding the acceptability of object omission. The answers are recorded on a 1-5 Likert scale. > *The next time Caroline talks about butchering chickens the day > before, how likely do you think she is to say the following?* > > 'I butchered yesterday' > > Cf. Glass [-@glassEnglishVerbsCan2021: 66] ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(survey$rating) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 4 2 5 1 ``` ::: ::: - `verb` contains the items to be rated for the conditions in `routine` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(survey$verb) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "pick" "catch" "throw" "break" "taste" "bottle" "sell" "chop" ``` ::: ::: - `frequency` relates to the frequency bins of the verbs: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(survey$freq) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "hi" "lo" ``` ::: ::: - `ParticipantID` identifies each of the 98 subjects who provided ratings ::: ## Modelling ordinal data Answering the research question means assessing how the features `routine` and `freq` affect the variability in the acceptability ratings. Furthermore, it is important to control for repeated measurements for `verb` and `ParticipantID`, which impose a hierarchical structure on the dataset. Formally speaking, we have $p$ explanatory variables $X_1, X_2, ..., X_p$ for $p \in \{1, ..., P\}$. The target variable `rating` is our target variable $Y$ with the ordered, discrete outcomes $y \in \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$. Our goal is to find a model $f$ that describes the relationship between $Y$ and $X_p$ as accurately as possible and minimises the error term $\epsilon$: $$ Y = f(X_1, X_2, ..., X_p) + \epsilon $$ ### Ordered logistic regression One family of models that respects the ordered, yet categorical nature of $Y$ is ordered (or ordinal) logistic regression. Other terms include **proportional odds models**, **cumulative logit/link models** etc. ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="Recap: Logistic regression"} Logistic regression is used to model categorical response variables with two or more levels. For instance, let's assume our $Y$ is dichotomous with the following two outcomes: $$ Y = \begin{cases} \text{yes} \\ \text{no} \end{cases} $$ Using the logistic function, we can estimate the probability of one outcome versus the other **given** the predictors $X_p$. Their log-transformed odds ratio (**log odds**) is equivalent of the all-too-familiar linear model: $$ \log\left(\frac{P(Y = yes \mid X_p)}{1 - P(Y = yes \mid X_p)}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_1 + ... + \beta_pX_p. $$ ::: Core to this approach is the notion of **cumulative probabilities**. Let $J$ denote the number of ordered categories in $Y$. In Glass's case study ($J = 5$), the estimated cumulative probabilities for each ordered outcome would have the following form: $$ \begin{array}{rcl} P(Y \leq 1) & = & P(Y = 1) \\ P(Y \leq 2) & = & P(Y = 1) + P(Y = 2) \\ P(Y \leq 3) & = & P(Y = 1) + P(Y = 2) + P(Y = 3) \\ P(Y \leq 4) & = & P(Y = 1) + P(Y = 2) + P(Y = 3) + P(Y = 4) \\ P(Y \leq 5) & = & P(Y = 1) + P(Y = 2) + P(Y = 3) + P(Y = 4) + P(Y = 5) \end{array} $$ We can generalise this pattern to $$ P(Y \leq j) = \hat{P_1} + ... + \hat{P_j} $$ We can now update our logistic regression equation to take into account cumulative probabilities: $$ \log\left(\frac{P(Y \leq j \mid X_p)}{1 - P(Y \leq j \mid X_p)}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_1 + ... + \beta_pX_p \qquad j = 1, ..., J-1 $$ ### Application in R ### Using `polr()` from the `MASS` library ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(MASS) # Convert to factor and determine ordering survey$rating <- factor(survey$rating, ordered = TRUE, levels = c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5")) # Fit polr model survey.polr <- polr(rating ~ freq + routine, data = survey) # Model summary summary(survey.polr) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(sjPlot) tab_model(survey.polr, show.se = TRUE, show.aic = TRUE, show.dev = TRUE, transform = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
  rating
Predictors Log-Odds std. Error CI p
1|2 -0.87 0.12 -1.11 – -0.63 <0.001
2|3 0.13 0.12 -0.10 – 0.37 0.259
3|4 1.25 0.13 1.00 – 1.51 <0.001
4|5 2.89 0.20 2.50 – 3.28 <0.001
freq [lo] -0.01 0.13 -0.26 – 0.24 0.932
routine [lo] -0.56 0.13 -0.81 – -0.30 <0.001
Observations 784
R2 Nagelkerke 0.024
Deviance 2246.662
AIC 2258.662
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Get diagnostics library(DescTools) PseudoR2(survey.polr, c("Nagelkerke", "AIC")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Nagelkerke AIC 0.0244793 2258.6617419 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Goodness-of-fit tests library(generalhoslem) lipsitz.test(survey.polr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Lipsitz goodness of fit test for ordinal response models data: formula: rating ~ freq + routine LR statistic = 20.261, df = 9, p-value = 0.01637 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pulkrob.chisq(survey.polr, catvars = c("freq", "routine")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pulkstenis-Robinson chi-squared test data: formula: rating ~ freq + routine X-squared = 21.476, df = 9, p-value = 0.0107 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Test proportional odds assumption library(brant) brant(survey.polr) # p < 0.05 is a violation of the assumption ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` -------------------------------------------- Test for X2 df probability -------------------------------------------- Omnibus 14.45 6 0.02 freqlo 6.5 3 0.09 routinelo 8.14 3 0.04 -------------------------------------------- H0: Parallel Regression Assumption holds ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Plot (best so far) library(effects) library(ggeffects) ## Frequency effect plot #plot(Effect(focal.predictors = c("freq"), mod = survey.polr), rug = FALSE, style = "stacked") ## Routine effect plot plot(Effect(focal.predictors = c("routine"), mod = survey.polr), rug = FALSE, style="stacked") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## Interaction #plot(Effect(focal.predictors = c("routine", "freq"), mod = survey.polr), rug = FALSE, # style="stacked") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggpubr) ggarrange(p1, p2, ncol = 2, common.legend = TRUE, legend = "right") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Using `clm()` from the `ordinal` library ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Convert to factor and determine ordering survey$rating <- factor(survey$rating, ordered = TRUE, levels = c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5")) # Fit cumulative link model clm.1 <- ordinal::clm(rating ~ freq + routine, data = survey, Hess=TRUE) # Model summary summary(clm.1) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tab_model(clm.1, show.se = TRUE, show.aic = TRUE, show.dev = TRUE, transform = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
  rating
Predictors Log-Odds std. Error CI p
1|2 -0.87 0.12 -1.11 – -0.63 <0.001
2|3 0.13 0.12 -0.10 – 0.37 0.259
3|4 1.25 0.13 1.00 – 1.51 <0.001
4|5 2.89 0.20 2.50 – 3.28 <0.001
freq [lo] -0.01 0.13 -0.26 – 0.24 0.932
routine [lo] -0.56 0.13 -0.81 – -0.30 <0.001
Observations 784
R2 Nagelkerke 0.024
AIC 2258.662
````` ::: ::: ### Mixed-effects ::: {.callout-note collapse="true" title="Recap: Mixed-effects models"} If the data is nested according to some grouping factor with $1, ..., K$ groups, we can let the intercept and/or slopes vary by group. For instance, recall the varying-intercept model: $$ Y = \alpha_{k} + \beta_1X_{1} + \beta_2X_{2} + ... + \epsilon \qquad \alpha_{j} \sim N(\mu_{\alpha}, \sigma_{\alpha}^2). $$ In this case we also speak of **random effects**. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Convert to factor and determine ordering survey$rating <- factor(survey$rating, ordered = TRUE, levels = c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5")) # Fit mixed model with random intercepts for "verb" and "ParticipantID" clm.2 <- ordinal::clmm(rating ~ freq * routine + (1 | verb) + (1 | ParticipantID), data = survey, Hess=TRUE) # Model summary summary(clm.2) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tab_model(clm.2, show.se = TRUE, show.aic = TRUE, show.dev = TRUE, transform = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
  rating
Predictors Log-Odds std. Error CI p
1|2 -1.36 0.40 -2.14 – -0.57 0.001
2|3 0.21 0.40 -0.58 – 0.99 0.605
3|4 1.83 0.41 1.04 – 2.63 <0.001
4|5 3.86 0.44 3.00 – 4.73 <0.001
freq [lo] -0.16 0.21 -0.58 – 0.26 0.463
routine [lo] -0.75 0.21 -1.16 – -0.34 <0.001
freq [lo] Ã— routine [lo] -0.14 0.30 -0.72 – 0.44 0.637
Random Effects
σ2 3.29
τ00 ParticipantID 2.06
τ00 verb 0.91
ICC 0.47
N verb 8
N ParticipantID 98
Observations 784
Marginal R2 / Conditional R2 0.028 / 0.489
AIC 2001.305
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Generalised additive models (GAMs) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(mgcv) library(itsadug) library(gratia) survey$ParticipantID <- as.factor(survey$ParticipantID) survey$verb <- as.factor(survey$verb) gam1 <- bam(as.numeric(rating) ~ freq + routine + s(ParticipantID, bs = "re") + s(verb, bs = "re"), data = survey, family = ocat(R=5) ) summary(gam1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Family: Ordered Categorical(-1,0.51,2.09,4.06) Link function: identity Formula: as.numeric(rating) ~ freq + routine + s(ParticipantID, bs = "re") + s(verb, bs = "re") Parametric coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 0.3613 0.3880 0.931 0.352 freqlo -0.2195 0.1431 -1.534 0.125 routinelo -0.7752 0.1428 -5.430 7.79e-08 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Approximate significance of smooth terms: edf Ref.df F p-value s(ParticipantID) 77.654 97 4.677 <2e-16 *** s(verb) 6.728 7 25.860 <2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Deviance explained = 27.3% fREML = 1631 Scale est. = 1 n = 784 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Extract the thresholds on the linear predictor from the model thresh <- gratia::theta(gam1) |> tibble::as_tibble() |> setNames(c("threshold")) routine_pred <- ggpredict(gam1, terms = "routine") routine_pred |> ggplot(aes(x = x, y = predicted)) + geom_point(col = "steelblue") + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high, width = 0), col = "steelblue") + #geom_line() + geom_hline(data = thresh, aes(yintercept = threshold), linetype = "dashed") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} verb_pred <- ggpredict(gam1, terms = "verb") verb_pred |> ggplot(aes(x = x, y = predicted)) + geom_point(col = "steelblue") + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high, width = 0), col = "steelblue") + #geom_line() + geom_hline(data = thresh, aes(yintercept = threshold), linetype = "dashed") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} subj_pred <- ggpredict(gam1, terms = "ParticipantID") subj_pred |> ggplot(aes(x = x, y = predicted)) + geom_point(col = "steelblue") + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high, width = 0), col = "steelblue") + #geom_line() + geom_hline(data = thresh, aes(yintercept = threshold), linetype = "dashed") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Ordinal_regression_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-3.png){width=672} ::: :::
